Author: Mary B. Coney, Michael Steedhouder
Title: Role Playing on the Web: Guidelines for Designing and Evaluating Personas Online
Evidence: We start from the premise that humans communicate through a series of roles that they assume appropriate to their rhetorical purposes.

Author: Mary B. Coney, Michael Steedhouder
Title: Role Playing on the Web: Guidelines for Designing and Evaluating Personas Online
Evidence: Personas are not real people, but they represent them throughout the process.

Author: Mary B. Coney, Michael Steedhouder
Title: Role Playing on the Web: Guidelines for Designing and Evaluating Personas Online
Evidence: ..he acknowledges [Cooper] that the inspirations for that persona lie in the designers' understanding of the actual users. one informs the other; isn't an either/or choice.

Author: Mary B. Coney, Michael Steedhouder
Title: Role Playing on the Web: Guidelines for Designing and Evaluating Personas Online
Evidence: Readers are not considered so much recipients of information as participants in a drama.

Author: Mary B. Coney, Michael Steedhouder
Title: Role Playing on the Web: Guidelines for Designing and Evaluating Personas Online
Evidence: Whenever writers or designers use some form of the word you, they are addressing not you, the complex person that you are in actual life, but the person they have imagined for their audience.

Author: Mary B. Coney, Michael Steedhouder
Title: Role Playing on the Web: Guidelines for Designing and Evaluating Personas Online
Evidence: New technologies retain power or control for the designer while only appearing to empower the user.

Author: Bianca Piazza
Title: We'll Forever Be Famous YouTuber Trisha Paytas's Little Baby Fishies
Evidence: Sometimes, with just enough drive and just enough audacity, a star is born.

Author: Bianca Piazza
Title: We'll Forever Be Famous YouTuber Trisha Paytas's Little Baby Fishies
Evidence: But what does Trish make videos about? What are they known for? Well, these are loaded questions.

Author: Bianca Piazza
Title: We'll Forever Be Famous YouTuber Trisha Paytas's Little Baby Fishies
Evidence: Put it this way, Trish - who has a background working in the sex industry - does everything and anything, and they do it all for the attention.

Author: Bianca Piazza
Title: We'll Forever Be Famous YouTuber Trisha Paytas's Little Baby Fishies
Evidence: Trish's ride to fame was an inherently messy one, as they were once known as the troll of YouTube.

Author: Bianca Piazza
Title: We'll Forever Be Famous YouTuber Trisha Paytas's Little Baby Fishies
Evidence: And though Trish has admitted to trolling for views on multiple occasions - detailing that they've dumbed themself down for views and assumed people wouldn't watch 'if I was just real and true to who I was.'

Author: Mikhaila Archer
Title: The (Sort-of) Evolution of Trisha Paytas
Evidence: Trisha has been - rightfully - criticized for offending basically every group on the planet and trying on different ethnicities and religions like costumes.

Author: Mikhaila Archer
Title: The (Sort-of) Evolution of Trisha Paytas
Evidence: However, a lot of people of have deemed her 'uncancellable,' concluding that 'you can't cancel someone who doesn't care.'

Author: Mikhaila Archer
Title: The (Sort-of) Evolution of Trisha Paytas
Evidence: It's often debated whether or not Trisha means the shocking things she says and does to her open admissions of trolling for attention, telling Vulture, 'I thought, like, I'm not really talented or anything, so maybe I just need to try and offend as many people as possible to get money.'

Author: Mikhaila Archer
Title: The (Sort-of) Evolution of Trisha Paytas
Evidence: Trisha, in her own complicated and often still problematic way, has created an entirely new presence as she uses her platform to speak out against injustices.

Author: Mikhaila Archer
Title: The (Sort-of) Evolution of Trisha Paytas
Evidence: Most notably, though, Trisha has become a beloved figure for consistently speaking out against abuse that happens within the YouTube community.

Author: Lori Kendall
Title: Meaning and Identity in "Cyberspace": The Performance of Gender, Class, and Race Online
Evidence: Yet people use assumptions about identity - including understandings of race, gender, age, and so forth - to organize their social world and inform their interactions.

Author: Lori Kendall
Title: Meaning and Identity in "Cyberspace": The Performance of Gender, Class, and Race Online
Evidence: Goffman (1974) suggests that despite the ability to adapt our presentation of self to accommodate different social situations, people resist viewing the self as a performed character.

Author: Lori Kendall
Title: Meaning and Identity in "Cyberspace": The Performance of Gender, Class, and Race Online
Evidence: Even online - where the performance of identity seems almost unavoidably obvious, where tales abound of multiplicity and fluidity, of deceptions and revelations, people persist in seeking essentialized grounds for the selves they encounter.

Author: Lori Kendall
Title: Meaning and Identity in "Cyberspace": The Performance of Gender, Class, and Race Online
Evidence: Although participants rarely refer directly to class and race online, they bring ideas and assumptions about these aspects of identity into their online interactions.

Author: Lori Kendall
Title: Meaning and Identity in "Cyberspace": The Performance of Gender, Class, and Race Online
Evidence: Several features of online interaction canr esult in gender identity enactments which rely to an even greater degree on stereotypical notions of identity than do offline enactments.

Author: Lori Kendall
Title: Meaning and Identity in "Cyberspace": The Performance of Gender, Class, and Race Online
Evidence: Participants gave greater weight to offline identity than online identity, and they continue to treat gender as immutable and rooted in the physical body.

Author: Lori Kendall
Title: Meaning and Identity in "Cyberspace": The Performance of Gender, Class, and Race Online
Evidence: As a consequence of the focus on individual attainment rather than social class structure, even people with relatively privileged class positions worry about their personal success and may percieve themselves as disadvantaged compared to others.

Author: Lori Kendall
Title: Meaning and Identity in "Cyberspace": The Performance of Gender, Class, and Race Online
Evidence: This [online spaces] provides opportunities for identity play and experimentation that potentially affect hierarchical relations and other power issues relevant to aspects of identity.

Author: Lori Kendall
Title: Meaning and Identity in "Cyberspace": The Performance of Gender, Class, and Race Online
Evidence: Participants' offline identities underlie their online identities and conversations.

Author: Elaine Replogle
Title: Fame, Social Media Use, and Ethics
Evidence: The underlying assumption was that if you're famous, one popular and currently very 'legitimate' way to deal with a difficult life event is to be intentionally public about it, and to (often) benefit from the sympathy and commiseration that follow.

Author: Elaine Replogle
Title: Fame, Social Media Use, and Ethics
Evidence: People understand that fame has to be carefully handled and cultivated and that honesty, particularly if it appears to come directly from the celebrity, is important if a good reputation is to be maintained.

Author: Elaine Replogle
Title: Fame, Social Media Use, and Ethics
Evidence: Social media allows anyone to disclose life trivia for all to see, making it possible for people to be percieved as beging for attention, of transgressing traditional boundaries of public and private, of acting somehow 'inappropriately.'

Author: Elaine Replogle
Title: Fame, Social Media Use, and Ethics
Evidence: The social support benefits of social media use should remind us that while the expectations of maintaining separate public and private lives persist, people will often forgo keeping something private if doing so brings them more support, reduces lonelieness, or increases their social capital.

Author: Manuel Arturo Abreu
Title: Transtrender: A Meditation on Gender as a Social Construct
Evidence: This [trans-trending] is a symptom of the recent generalization of queerness as any marketable deviation from norm.

Author: Manuel Arturo Abreu
Title: Transtrender: A Meditation on Gender as a Social Construct
Evidence: When did queerness become a post-critical theory clickbait machine?

Author: Manuel Arturo Abreu
Title: Transtrender: A Meditation on Gender as a Social Construct
Evidence: The mainstream, whitewashed image of the suffering trans person gains much of its traction from sociological statistics about trans of color circumstances.

Author: Manuel Arturo Abreu
Title: Transtrender: A Meditation on Gender as a Social Construct
Evidence: Just as queerness has been generalized to encompass all norm deviation in nature, trans has been generalized, leaving the realm of gender to describe other neural, social, and eeconomic circumstances.

Author: Manuel Arturo Abreu
Title: Transtrender: A Meditation on Gender as a Social Construct
Evidence: The "space" of gender and sexuality, consisting of performativities, identities, orientations, and so forth, is made possible by the radicalized logic of visible difference, which has its roots in slavery and its afterlife.

Author: Manuel Arturo Abreu
Title: Transtrender: A Meditation on Gender as a Social Construct
Evidence: At its white heart, trans is a regime of gender legibility, be it medical evidence or performing identity politics.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: Within the feminist movement racial conflict between white women and women of colour continues to be one area of struggle.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: Women are divided by sexist attitudes, racism, class privilege, and a host of other prejudices.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: Sexist ideology teaches women that to be female is to be a victim.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: Ironically, the women who were most eager to be seen as 'victims,' who overwhelmingly stressed the role of victim, were more prvilieged and powerful than the vast majority of women in our society.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: Identifying as 'victims,' they could abdicate responsibility for their role in the maintenance and perpetuation of sexism, racism, and classism, which they did by insisting that only men were the enemy.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: Their [white womens'] version of Sisterhood was informed by racist and classist assumptions about white womanhood, that the white 'lady' (that is to say bourgeois woman) should be protected from all that might upset or discomfort her and shielded from negative realities that might lead to confrontation.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: Historically, many black women experienced white women as the white supremacist group who most directly exercised power over them, often in a manner far more brutal and dehumanizing than that of racist white men.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: White females discriminate against and exploit black women while simultaneously being envious and competitive in their interactions with them.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: When white women attack white supremacy, they are simultaneously pariticipating in the struggle to end sexist oppression.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: Racism allows white women to construct feminist theory and praxis in such a way that it is far removed from anything resembling radical struggle.

Author: Bell Hooks
Title: Political Solidarity Between Women
Evidence: Expression of hostility as an end in itself is a useless activity, but when it is the catalyst pushing us on to greater clarity and understanding, it serves a meaningful function.

Author: Jessie Daniels
Title: Rethinking Cyberfeminism(s): Race, Gender and Embodiment
Evidence: As Sassen notes, there is no 'purely digital' or exclusively 'virtual' electronic space; rather, the digital is always 'embedded' in the material.

Author: Jessie Daniels
Title: Rethinking Cyberfeminism(s): Race, Gender and Embodiment
Evidence: Additional research into actual online practices suggests that rather than going online to 'switch' gender or racial identities along axes of race, gender and sexuality.

Author: Jessie Daniels
Title: Rethinking Cyberfeminism(s): Race, Gender and Embodiment
Evidence: The absence of the physical body in electronic space and the anonymity this offers have a liberating effect on repressed social identity, as 'electronic technology' becomes 'a tool for the design of freely 'chosen identities.'

Author: Jessie Daniels
Title: Rethinking Cyberfeminism(s): Race, Gender and Embodiment
Evidence: The putative invisibility online and the 'decoupling identity from any analogical relation to the visible body' to escape race and gender visibility rests on an assumption of an exclusively text-based online world that belies the reality of digital video and photographic technologies, such as webcams (and image-sharing sites, among them Flickr and YouTube), which make images of bodies a quotidian part of the gendered and racialized, online world.

Author: Jessie Daniels
Title: Rethinking Cyberfeminism(s): Race, Gender and Embodiment
Evidence: While those participating in pro-ana sites may appear to be ambivalent about their own embodiment, the fact is that they are not going online to avoid corporeality but rather to enage with others about their bodies via text and image in ways that make them feel in control of those bodies.

Author: Jessie Daniels
Title: Rethinking Cyberfeminism(s): Race, Gender and Embodiment
Evidence: The whiteness that Kendall describes in BlueSky is very much like whiteness in the offline world: an unmarked category that is taken for granted in daily life.

Author: Jessie Daniels
Title: Rethinking Cyberfeminism(s): Race, Gender and Embodiment
Evidence: Race matters in cyberspace precisely because 'computer networks are social networks' and those who spend time online bring their own knowledge, experiences, and values with them when they log on.

Author: Jessie Daniels
Title: Rethinking Cyberfeminism(s): Race, Gender and Embodiment
Evidence: In both instances, self-identified girls and women engage in practices with Internet technologies to manage, transform, and control their physical bodies in ways that both resist and reinforce hierarchies of gender and race.

Author: Jessie Daniels
Title: Rethinking Cyberfeminism(s): Race, Gender and Embodiment
Evidence: Girls and self-identified women are engaging with Internet technologies in ways that enable them to transform their embodied selves, not escape embodiment.
